questions.text: The chemotherapeutic agent sunitinib is effectively used for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Sunitinib is a small molecule, multi-targeted kinase antagonist/inhibitor and has been shown to have anti-tumor activity in renal cell carcinoma (RCC), gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNETs).
  • Pharmacology of sunitinib:
    • Molecular targets of sunitinib are c-Kit, VEGFR-2, PDGFR-β and Flt-3.
    • Sunitinib targets mutations in the RET gene.
    • The mechanisms of sunitinib’s action are:
      • Inhibition of activated c-Kit and PDGFR in GIST
      • Inhibition of VEGFR in advanced RCC
  • Adverse effects:
    • Its specific adverse effects include neutropenia, diarrhea and fatigue.
    • Generally, the other common side effects of agents having anti-VEGFR activity are hypertension and proteinuria.
    • Rarely, they cause bleeding and clotting disorders, and perforation of scarred gastrointestinal lesions.
    • Hand-foot syndrome has also been noted in the use of these agents, with erythema and desquamation of distal extremities.
  • Administration:
    • In advanced RCC and in adjuvant therapy, sunitinib is given orally, at a dose of 50mg per day, once daily, with or without food, for 4 weeks out of 6 (nine 6-week cycles in adjuvant therapy).
  • Uses:
    • In metastatic GIST, the main chemotherapeutic agent used is imatinib, which is a selective inhibitor of the c-kit tyrosine kinase. Patients whose tumors have become refractory to imatinib benefit from agents like sunitinib, which also inhibits c-kit tyrosine kinase.
    • It is now undergoing studies for efficacy in hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Update:
    • The drug was previously approved for use by various regulatory bodies in 2006, for conditions like GIST and advanced RCC.
    • In 2017, sunitinib malate was approved by the FDA for use as adjuvant therapy for patients at risk for recurrence of RCC after a kidney has been removed (nephrectomy).
    • This was based on a multi-center, international, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial among 615 patients with high risk of recurrent RCC following nephrectomy.

questions.text: Mucopolysaccharidosis type VII has the eponym:
questions.solution:
• Mucopolysaccharidosis type VII (MPS VII) is also called Sly syndrome.
  • It is a rare lysosomal storage disease and an autosomal recessive disorder where there is deficiency of β-glucuronidase.
  • Neonatal form of Sly syndrome presents with fetal hydrops.
  • Infantile and adult forms of this disease have wide-ranging clinical features which include skeletal dysplasia, corneal clouding, leucocytic inclusions, coarse facies, etc. Mental retardation may develop in the infantile form but adults rarely manifest it.
  • Update:
    • Vestronidase alfa-vbjk has been approved by the American regulatory body FDA, in 2017, for use in treatment of mucopolysaccharidosis type VII (MPS VII) in adults and pediatric patients.
    • Vestronidase alfa-vjbk is a recombinant human enzyme that is intended to provide exogenous β-glucuronidase for uptake into cellular lysosome.
    • It is given as an intravenous infusion.
    • Side effects related to the administration of this drug are infusion site reaction, anaphylaxis, diarrhea and rash. The CNS effects of this drug have not been determined.
  • MPS I S is called Scheie syndrome. MPS II is called Hunter syndrome and MPS VI is called Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the WHO Baby-Friendly Hospital Initiative for small, sick, and preterm newborns (2020)?

choices.text: Paladai feeding is indicated in very preterm infants with no suck-swallow-breath coordination
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge
Feeding tubes are indicated only in neurologically compromised infants for long-term use
Bottle feeding can lead to overfeeding but has a reduced risk of aspiration in infants with immature suck-swallow-breathe reflex

questions.solution:
Finger-feeding is optimally indicated for short-term use and may improve breastfeeding rates at discharge. Hence, statement 2 is correct. It is indicated in neurologically compromised and preterm infants for a short period.

The image below depicts how finger-feeding is done.

Paladai feeding is indicated in preterm infants (32-34 weeks) and term infants for supplementation. It can be for short or long-term use. It is a useful measure in low-medium income countries and is easy to use and clean. It has a risk of aspiration and is a slower method of feeding. The oro-motor movements are different as compared to that of breastfeeding. It is not indicated for very preterm infants.

Feeding tubes i.e. orogastric or nasogastric tubes are an efficient way of measuring intake. It is optimally used in very preterm infants (28-31 weeks) with no suck-swallow-breathe coordination for long-term use. It is an expensive measure as it requires frequent replacement.

Bottle and teat feeding, though not recommended is an efficient way to feed. Slow-flow teats mimic breastfeeding and are preferred to rapid-flow teats. They allow overfeeding and there is a risk of aspiration with immature suck-swallow-breathe coordination.

BFHI is a global effort (sponsored by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Children's Fund) to promote breastfeeding. It recommends 10 steps to successful breastfeeding. The ten steps are attached in the pearl below.

World Breastfeeding Week is celebrated every year from 1 to 7 August to encourage breastfeeding and improve the health of babies around the world.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A 26 years old pregnant woman attended a camp in her village for screening of syphilis, as the village has reported high prevalence of syphilis cases. Which of the following tests are recommended?

choices.text: Single on-site rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test
Onsite RST, if positive, provision of first dose of treatment followed by RPR test
Onsite RPR test, if positive, provision of first dose of treatment followed by RST

questions.solution:
Onsite RST, if positive, provision of first dose of treatment followed by RPR test is recommended for screening of pregnant women for syphilis in places with high prevalence of syphilis (5% or greater).

  • The recently proposed guidelines by WHO on syphilis screening and treatment for pregnant women recommends screening of all pregnant women for syphilis during the first antenatal care visit.

Screening Strategies:

Facilities / Prevalence of syphilis Recommended screening strategy
Low prevalence of syphilis (below 5%) Single on-site rapid syphilis test (RST) (Strategy A) is recommended over the single on-site raid plasma reagin test (RPR) (Strategy B)
High prevalence of syphilis (5% or greater)
  • On-site rapid syphilis test (RST)

If positive,

  • Provision of a first dose of treatment and a rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test

If positive,

  • Provision of treatment according to duration of syphilis (Strategy C)
In places with low coverage of syphilis screening and treatment for pregnant women On-site tests (Strategies A, B, and C) rather than the standard off-site laboratory-based screening and treatment strategy.(Strategy D)

questions.text: The recently FDA approved drug, letermovir, is used against which virus in hematopoietic stem cell recipients?
questions.solution:
• Letermovir is used against cytomegalovirus.
  • Pharmacology:
    • Letermovir is a dihydroquinozoline that acts through the inhibition of viral terminase enzyme complex.
    • This drug is used as a prophylactic agent against cytomegalovirus (CMV) in adult CMV-seropositive, allogenic hematopoietic stem cell recipients (bone marrow transplant).
    • An added benefit of this drug is that it is active against CMV isolates that are resistant to other drugs.
  • Administration:
    • It is administered orally or intravenously, at a dose of 480 mg once per day, for 100 days post-transplant.
  • Drug interactions and adverse effects:
    • It is contraindicated with the use of pimozide, ergot alkaloids; and pitavastatin and simvastatin when co-administered with cyclosporine.
    • Adverse reactions of this drug include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, peripheral edema, cough, headache, fatigue and abdominal pain
  • Update:
    • Letermovir was approved for this usage in November 2017 by the US FDA.

questions.text: The novel prostaglandin agonist called latanoprostene bunod is to be used for which of the following purposes?
questions.solution:
• Latanoprostene bunod (LBN) is an ophthalmic solution which is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension.
  • It is an NO-donating prostaglandin F2 alpha receptor agonist.
  • It reduces the intraocular pressure by increasing aqueous outflow through the trabecular meshwork and uveoscleral routes.
  • Common side-effects include conjunctival hyperemia, eye irritation and pain in the instillation site.
  • It is administered as eye drops to be instilled once a day in the evening.
  • If other drugs are being used for the eye, it has to be given 5 minutes apart.
  • It was approved for this usage by the FDA in 2017.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the integrated care for older people (ICOPE) guidelines recently released by WHO?

choices.text: Integrated health care to maintain only the mental capacities of older people
Multimodal exercise to improve  musculoskeletal function
Self-management is not recommended for older people

questions.solution:
• According to the recent ICOPE guidelines released by WHO, Multimodal exercise, including progressive strength resistance training is recommended to improve musculoskeletal function, mobility and vitality.
  • Other exercise components such as balance, flexibility and aerobic training should be recommended for older people with declining physical capacity, measured by gait speed, grip strength and other physical performance measures

Other options:

  • Option a: Integrated health care provided as per ICOPE will enable an older person to maintain their physical and mental capacities.
  • Option b: Community outreach and home-based interventions are recommended.
  • Option d: Support for self-management is provided for the older people.

questions.text: Species specific prevalence rate is considered for providing preventive chemotherapy for soil-transmitted helminth infections in which of the following risk groups?
questions.solution:
Species specific prevalence rate has been considered for the pregnant woman in the recently released WHO guidelines for deworming.

Rationale for considering species specific prevalence rate among pregnant women for deworming:

  • The morbidity caused by the different soil-transmitted helminths is species-specific
  • Hookworm and T. trichiura infections cause anaemia, which is particularly detrimental for pregnant women, while morbidity due to A. lumbricoides is less relevant for this group

Recommendation: pregnant women in the second or third trimester

Preventive chemotherapy (deworming), using single-dose albendazole (400 mg) or mebendazole (500 mg), is recommended for pregnant women, after the first trimester, living in areas where both:

  • The baseline prevalence of hookworm and/or T. trichiura infection is 20% or more among pregnant women, and
  • Anaemia is a severe public health problem, with a prevalence of 40% or higher among pregnant women.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-protozoal drugs is preferred for the treatment of the disease predominantly transmitted by the vector in the given image?
questions.solution:
The vector given in the image is a Reduviid bug which is also called the kissing bug or triatomine. They are responsible for the transmission of Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) which is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi.

Benznidazole is used in the treatment of Chagas disease. Another widely used drug for its treatment is nifurtimox. But benznidazole is the preferred treatment due to toxicity issues.

Benznidazole generates oxygen radicals and nitro radical anions which account for its trypanocidal effect.

It is given orally at doses of 5-7 mg/kg per day in two divided doses for 60 days in those above 13 years and for children 12 years and below, the dose 10 mg/kg per day for the same schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the novel drug regimen, glecaprevir + pibrentasvir for hepatitis C infection?

choices.text: Not recommended in patients with decompensated cirrhosis
Not recommended in patients undergoing dialysis
Recommended for treatment-naïve patients with HCV genotype 1-6

questions.solution:
• The combination regimen of glecaprevir (100mg) and pibrentasvir (40mg) is used to treat hepatitis C virus (HCV) infections in adults under particular indications.
  • Indications:
    • It is indicated in treatment-naïve adults with chronic HCV infections from HCV genotypes 1-6, without cirrhosis or with compensated cirrhosis.
    • It is also indicated in the treatment of adults with chronic HCV who have been previously treated with a regimen containing either non-structural protein 5A (NS5A) inhibitor or an NS3/4A protease inhibitor but not both.
    • It can also be used in patients with moderate to severe kidney disease and those who are on dialysis.
  • Pharmacology:
    • Glecaprevir is an HCV NS3/4A protease inhibitor and pibrentasvir is an HCV NS5A inhibitor.
  • Contraindications and adverse effects:
    • It is contraindicated in usage with rifampin & atazanavir, severe hepatic impairment.
    • Adverse effects include headache, fatigue, nausea, diarrhea and increased bilirubin.
  • Duration of the treatment with this regimen depends upon treatment history, viral genotype and cirrhosis status.
  • It is given orally.
  • Update:
    • It was approved by regulatory bodies for usage in 2017, in US and Europe.
    • It is distributed under the trade name Mavyret.
    • Another regimen for HCV infection that has been recently approved is sofosbuvir + velpatasvir + volxilaprevir.

questions.text: According to WHO classification the nutritional status of a 24-month old child is being classified as severe acute malnutrition, when ________
questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition:

In infants and children under 5 years of age, refers to 

  • Weight-for length/height more than 3 SD below the median (< –3SD) of the WHO child growth standards

Or

  • Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Or

  • Clinical signs of bilateral pitting oedema of nutritional origin.

 

Update:

WHO in october 2017, has released guidelines for Assessing and managing children at primary health-care facilities to prevent overweight and obesity in the context of the double burden of malnutrition.

Three specific areas and related questions were prioritized in the guidelines:

(i) Anthropometric assessment and classification of the nutritional status of infants and children presenting to primary health-care facilities

(ii) Management of infants and children with acute or chronic malnutrition presenting to primary health-care facilities

(iii) Management of children who are overweight or obese presenting to primary health-care facilities.

 

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: A 19 year old boy, weighing 62kgs, is suffering from visceral leishmaniasis. The recommended dosage for miltefosine is _______
questions.solution:
The accelerated plan for Kala-Azar elimination released by Ministry of Health and Family Welfare suggests the treatment regimens for visceral leishmaniasis.

The dosage of oral miltefosine for treatment of visceral leishmaniasis is as follows:

  • For children aged 2 – 11 years: 2.5mg/kg/day for 28 days
  • For people aged more than 12 years, and body weight<25kgs:
    • <25 Kgs: 50mg/day for 28 days
    • 25 – 50 Kgs: 100mg/day for 28 days
    • >50 Kgs: 150 mg/day for 28 days

 

Note: Single dose single day treatment with Liposomal Amphotericin B injection is the first drug of choice followed by capsule Miltefosine (28 days) and injection Amphotericin B (15 injections on alternate days) as well as combination of Miltefosine and Paromomycin injection.

questions.text: Pick the new anti-coagulant from the following line-up that has recently been approved for usage in the prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in medically ill patients.
questions.solution:
• Betrixaban is a novel anticoagulant used for extended duration prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism in adults who are hospitalized with an acute medical illness.
  • Indications:
    • It is indicated if the patient is at risk for thromboembolic complications due to moderate or severe restricted mobility and has other risk factors for the same.
  • Pharmacology:
    • Betrixaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor that selectively blocks the active site of factor Xa. It doesn’t require a co-factor. By this method, it decreases thrombin aggregation.
  • Administration:
    • It is an oral capsule that is given at a dose of 160mg on day 1, followed by 80mg once daily, taken for the duration of 35 to 42 days, at the same time each day with food.
  • Adverse effects:
    • Most adverse effects related to betrixaban relate to bleeding like epistaxis, intracranial hemorrhage, etc. But the incidence of non-major bleeding is higher than that of major bleeding.
  • Update:
    • It was approved for this usage by the U.S. FDA in 2017.
  • Apixaban is a factor Xa inhibitor that is used not only in the treatment of VTE/DVT but also in its prophylaxis after major orthopedic surgery.
  • Dalteparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). It is mostly used in the treatment of VTE in cancer patients. It is also used in prophylaxis of VTE/DVT following orthopedic surgery and other major surgeries.
  • Fondaparinux is an anti-thrombotic agent which is chemically related to LMWH. It is mostly used in the treatment of VTE and pulmonary embolism. It also has use in the prophylaxis of VTE after major surgery or in medically ill patients.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of patients with plaque psoriasis is an interleukin-23 inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Guselkumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits interleukin-23 by binding to its p19 subunit. By this, it inhibits the pro-inflammatory actions of IL-23, decreasing cytokine and chemokine release.

It is indicated for use in moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis, when the patient is a possible candidate for systemic therapy or if early systemic therapy is the logical option for a patient. It is given as a subcutaneous injection at a dose of 100mg at week 0, week 4 and every 8 weeks thereafter.

Adverse effects of guselkumab include the risk of general infections and upper respiratory tract infections (most common). Other adverse events include headache, injection site reaction, arthralgia, diarrhea, gastroenteritis, and tinea infections.

 Other Options:

  • Brodalumab is a fully human IL-17RA monoclonal antibody that inhibits the interaction of IL-17 with cytokines. It also received approval for usage in plaque psoriasis.
  • Ixekizumab is also indicated for use in plaque psoriasis. It neutralizes the pro-inflammatory effects of IL-17A by inhibition.
  • Etanercept is a tumor necrosis factor-α (TNFα) inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of conditions like ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis (adult and juvenile), psoriatic arthritis and plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about national strategic plan for malaria elimination 2017 – 2022?

choices.text: The strategy focuses on the states and union territories as the operational units
Reduce transmission in category 2 districts by 2022
Eliminate malaria in category 1 districts by 2022
Eliminate malaria in category 1 districts by 2020

questions.solution:
The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP. The strategy focuses on the districts which acts as the operational units.

Goals of National Strategic Plan for Malaria elimination are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1 - 2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts by to stabilize API at less than 1 by 2022

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: True statement regarding the DGHS guidelines for seasonal Influenza vaccination, for the period 2017 - 2018 is:

choices.text: Health Care workers treating influenza patients need not be vaccinated
Vaccine is not recommended for pregnant women
Trivalent vaccine for children between 6 months and 8 years of age
Quadrivalent vaccine for elderly individuals more than 65 years of age

questions.solution:
Guidelines for Seasonal Influenza Vaccination 2017-2018:

The Directorate General of Health Services has recently updated guidelines for vaccination with Influenza Vaccine.

Type of vaccine: Trivalent inactivated influenza vaccines which are made to protect against three flu viruses; an influenza A (H1N1) virus, an influenza A (H3N2) virus, and an influenza B virus.

Persons recommended for vaccination:

  1. Health Care workers, working in hospital / institutional settings (doctors, nurses, paramedics) with likelihood of exposure to Influenza virus should be vaccinated.
  2. Seasonal Influenza may affect all age groups; globally incidence is higher in young children between 6 months to 8 years of age, and those above 65 years. Hence it is desirable to vaccinate these age groups.
  3. Vaccine is recommended for pregnant women, irrespective of the duration of pregnancy.
  4. For adults and children with chronic illnesses

questions.text: A 45-year old patient with Huntington’s disease has progressive chorea, dementia, progressive weight loss, non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus and suicidal ideation. He has not been on any type of medication till now. Based on the history, which feature excludes this patient from the usage of deutetrabenazine?
questions.solution:
• The novel drug deutetrabenazine has been shown to increase the risk of depression and suicidal ideation. Patients on this drug with history of this must be carefully monitored. It is contraindicated in cases of suicidal ideation and untreated/inadequately treated depression.
  • Deutetrabenazine is a vesicular monoamine transporter-2 (VMAT-2) inhibitor by which it decreases the uptake of monoamines into synaptic vesicles and depletes monoamine stores from nerve terminals.
  • This drug is indicated for use in the presence of chorea associated with Huntington’s disease.
  • It is given orally as a tablet at a starting dose of 6 mg once daily. It must be titrated up, at weekly intervals, by 6 mg per day up to a dose that reduces chorea and up to a maximum of 48 mg per day.
  • It also has use in tardive dyskinesia.
  • It is contraindicated in hepatic impairment and with the usage of other drugs like linezolid, reserpine, selegiline, etc.
  • Some adverse effects of deutetrabenazine are somnolence, diarrhea, dry mouth, fatigue, constipations, anxiety, etc.
  • Update:
    • This drug was approved by the U.S. FDA in 2017.

questions.text: The drug bortezomib has been proved to be at the centre of treatment of multiple myeloma. This injectable drug was recently approved in India for the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• Bortezomib is an inhibitor of proteasome-mediated protein degradation.
  • It is central to the treatment of multiple myeloma, both untreated and relapsed.
  • It has now become a first-line treatment option for mantle cell lymphoma, both untreated and refractory.
  • Bortezomib is given intravenously or subcutaneously and dosage depends upon the disease, route of administration and the patient’s history.
  • Adverse effects include thrombocytopenia, fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, neutropenia, anemia, anorexia, nausea, limb pain, dizziness, etc.
  • Other adverse events like cardiac tamponade, disseminated intravascular coagulation, toxic epidermal necrolysis, etc. have been reported.
  • Update:
    • The drug was approved in India in 2017 for the treatment of patients with mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the HIV and AIDS (Prevention and Control) Act, 2017, except:

choices.text: Prohibition of discrimination against HIV positive persons
A person between the age of 12 to 18 years can act as guardian to other sibling in an HIV affected family
HIV positive persons above the age of 21 years do not have the right to reside in a shared household
Informed consent is mandatory for performing HIV test

questions.solution:
As per the provisions of the HIV and AIDS (Prevention and Control) Act, 2017, every HIV positive person who is protected have the right to reside in a shared household, and enjoy the facilities of the household. There is no age limit to the provision of shared household.

Related Pearl: HIV and AIDS (Prevention and Control) Act, 2017

The Govt. of India on 21st April 2017, enacted the human immunodeficiency virus and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (prevention and control) act, 2017

Key highlights of the HIV and AIDS (Prevention and Control) Act, 2017

  • Prohibition of discrimination against HIV positive persons: The Bill sets various grounds on which discrimination against HIV positive persons is prohibited.  These include the denial, termination, discontinuation or unfair treatment with regard to employment, educational establishments, health care services, residing or renting property, among others.
  • Informed consent and disclosure of HIV status: The Bill requires that no HIV test, medical treatment, or research will be conducted on a person without his informed consent.
  • Role of the Union and State Governments: The Union and State Governments shall take measures to prevent the spread of HIV or AIDS, provide anti-retroviral therapy and infection management for persons with HIV or AIDS, and facilitate their access to welfare schemes especially for women and children, and others.
  • Role of the Ombudsman: An ombudsman shall be appointed by each state government to inquire into complaints related to the violation of the Act and the provision of health care services.
  • Guardianship: A person between the age of 12 to 18 years who has sufficient maturity in understanding and managing the affairs of his HIV or AIDS affected family shall be competent to act as a guardian of another sibling below 18 years of age.
  • Shared residence: Every protected HIV positive person has the right to reside in a shared household, and enjoy the facilities of the household.
  • Court proceedings: Cases relating to HIV positive persons shall be disposed of by the court on a priority basis.  In any legal proceeding, if an HIV infected or affected person is a party, the court may pass orders that the proceedings be conducted (a) by suppressing the identity of the person, (b) in camera, and (c) to restrain any person from publishing information that discloses the identity of the applicant.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with regards to the Ending Cholera—A Global Roadmap to 2030, recently released by the WHO - Global Task Force on Cholera Control (GTFCC)?

choices.text: GTFCC will support the countries to reduce cholera deaths by 60 percent
The large scale use of Oral Cholera Vaccine is recommended

questions.solution:
• Ending Cholera—A Global Roadmap to 2030, is a strategy released by the WHO Global Task Force on Cholera Control (GTFCC). By implementing the strategy between 2017 and 2030, the GTFCC partners will support countries to reduce cholera deaths by 90 percent.
  • Large-scale use of Oral Cholera Vaccine (OCV) has been recommended to immediately reduce disease burden while longer-term cholera control strategies are put in place.

questions.text: A 60 year old female is diagnosed with melanoma. On examination, a palpable lymph node was present in the posterior triangle. Biopsy revealed presence of tumour cells. Which of the following drugs used in this condition is a MEK inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Trametinib is a reversible inhibitor of mitogen-activated extracellular signal regulated kinase (MEK). It inhibits the serine-threonine kinase domain of BRAF V600E mutant of MEK.

It is widely used in the treatment of metastatic or unresectable melanoma

It can be used as a single agent but it is more effective when used with BRAF inhibitors like dabrafenib.

Adverse effects of this drug include rash, diarrhea, increased ALT, abdominal pain, stomatitis, increased AST, anemia, etc.

Dabrafenib and vemurafenib are BRAF inhibitors used in metastatic melanoma.

Ipilimumab is a human cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen 4 (CTLA-4) blocking antibody used in metastatic or unresectable melanoma.

Recent update: The FDA has approved the combination of the BRAF inhibitor encorafenib and the MEK inhibitor binimetinib for the treatment of patients with BRAF-mutant unresectable or metastatic melanoma.

questions.text: A 30 year old patient’s history shows a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase and he has the following bone marrow picture. He has been prescribed eliglustat as one of the drugs in his treatment. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Gaucher’s disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from the mutation of a gene that encodes glucocerebrosidase, which leads to its deficiency. This causes accumulation of glucosylceramide.
  • Gaucher’s disease are of type 1 (nonneuronopathic disease), type 2 and type 3 with different levels of neurological involvement.
  • Other common clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasia.
  • The given image shows Gaucher cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages resulting from the nonuniform infiltration of bone marrow. They give a ‘wrinkled tissue paper’ appearance.
  • Eliglustat
    • It is a specific inhibitor of glucosylceramide synthase and thus it is used in the treatment of Gaucher’s disease.
    • This drug is indicated in adults with Gaucher’s disease type 1, who are cytochrome P450 2D6 (CYP2D6) extensive metabolizers (EM), intermediate metabolizers (IM) or poor metabolizers (PM).
    • It is contraindicated in use with drugs like cocaine, bortezomib, clozapine, disulfiram, etc.
    • Adverse effects of this drug include arthralgia, headache, fatigue, diarrhea, etc.
    • Update:
      • It was approved for usage in India in 2017.
  • Niemann-Pick disease constitutes deficiency of sphingomyelinase.
  • Pompe disease is glycogen storage disease type II, in which there is deficiency of lysosomal acid α-glucosidase.
  • In Farber disease, there is deficiency of acid ceramidase.

questions.text: All of the following are considered as rape, except_______

choices.text: Intercourse with a girl < 18 years of age, without consent
Intercourse with wife less than 18 years of age
Intercourse with a girl, below 16 years of age, with consent
Intercourse with a girl, above 18 years of age, with consent

questions.solution:
Intercourse with a girl, above 18 years of age, with consent is not considered rape.

Clause ‘Sixthly’ of Section 375 makes it clear that if the woman is under 18 years of age, then sexual intercourse with her, with or without her consent is rape. This is commonly referred to as ‘statutory rape’ in which the willingness or consent of a woman below the age of 18 years for having sexual intercourse is rendered irrelevant and inconsequential.

Hence, Exception 2 to Section 375 IPC says that “sexual intercourse or sexual acts by a man with his own wife, the wife not being 18 years (i.e above the age of 18), is not rape”.

A man is said to commit “rape” if he has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the six following descriptions:

  • Against her will.
  • Without her consent.
  • With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested in fear of death or of hurt.
  • With her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband, and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married.
  • With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.
  • With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following blood pressure readings is considered as elevated blood pressure as per new ACC/AHA guidelines?
questions.solution:
120/78 mmHg is considered as an elevated BP (SBP 120 – 129 mmHg and DBP <80mmHg). All other options are Stage I hypertension.

  • The American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) have released a new guideline on hypertension with a new definition that will call 130 to 139 mm Hg systolic or 80 to 89 mm Hg, stage 1 hypertension.
  • The definition of normal blood pressure hasn't changed from the previous document
  • However the new guidelines eliminate the classification of prehypertension and divide those blood-pressure levels previously called prehypertension into elevated BP, with a systolic pressure between 120 and 129 and diastolic pressure less than 80 mm Hg, and stage 1 hypertension, which they now define as a systolic pressure 130 to 139 or a diastolic pressure of 80 to 89 mm Hg.

Related Pearl: Revised 2017 ACC guidelines on Hypertension:

  Systolic BP (mm Hg) Diastolic BP (mm Hg) Management
Normal  < 120 < 80 Lifestyle modification
Elevated BP 120 -129 < 80 Lifestyle modification
Stage 1 HT 130 -139 (or) 80 -89

Lifestyle modification(Antihypertensive medication only if

  • Previous stroke / CAD / Heart attack
  • Diabetic
  • CKD
Stage 2 HT > 140 (or)  > 90 Anti-hypertensive medication + Lifestyle modification
Hypertensive crisis > 180 (or) >120 Patients needing prompt changes in medication if there are no other indications of problems, or immediate hospitalization if there are signs of organ damage.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding pasireotide except:

choices.text: It is a cyclopentapeptide somatostatin analogue
It is used in treatment of acromegaly
It has affinity for most somatostatin receptors
It evokes an impairment in glycemic control

questions.solution:
• Pasireotide is a cyclohexapeptide somatostatin analogue.
  • It has a broader selectivity than other analogues like octreotide and binds with high affinity to most somatostatin receptors.
  • Its usage is indicated in the treatment of acromegaly in patients for whom surgery has not provided an adequate response and/or in those for whom surgery is not an option.
  • It is also indicated in Cushing’s disease where pituitary surgery is not an option or has not been curative.
  • Adverse effects include impairment in glycemic control, diarrhea, nausea, asthenia, alopecia, etc.
  • It can be given as a subcutaneous or intramuscular injection.
  • Update:
    • It was approved for usage in acromegaly, in India, in 2017, as an additional indication.

questions.text: Prucalopride was approved in India and the U.S. FDA approved plecanatide; both in 2017. What are these drugs used for?
questions.solution:
Prucalopride:

  • Prucalopride is a selective, high-affinity 5HT4 agonist
  • It was approved for usage in India in 2017 for chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC) to provide relief in case of laxative failure
  • It improves colonic transit and stool frequency
  • Side effects include headache, nausea and diarrhea
  • It is yet to gain approval in the United States but has in Europe

Plecantide:

  • Plecanatide is a guanylate cyclase-C agonist that is indicated for adults with CIC.
  • The recommended dose in 3mg, orally, once daily.
  • Adverse reactions include diarrhea and consequent dehydration.
  • It was approved for usage in the United States in 2017.

questions.text: The theme of World Health Day, 2017 was _______
questions.solution:
• World Health Day will be celebrated on April 7 every year.
  • Each year, the World Health Organisation (WHO) selects a theme highlighting a particular priority area of public health.
  • The theme for 2017 world health day is 'Depression: Let's Talk'.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the SAGE 2017 recommendations for typhoid vaccine?

choices.text: Introduction of Typhoid conjugate vaccine to infants above 1 month of age
It is administered in three doses, 6 months apart
It is administered in two doses, 6 months apart
Catch-up vaccination is recommended in the age group below 15 years

questions.solution:
The Strategic Advisory Group of Experts (SAGE) on Immunization met on 17-19 October 2017 in Geneva, Switzerland. SAGE makes new recommendations to prevent typhoid fever, rabies:

SAGE recommendation on Typhoid vaccines:

Due to continued high burden of typhoid fever and the alarming increase in antimicrobial resistance of Salmonella Typhi (S. Typhi) in low- and middle-income countries, SAGE re-emphasized the importance of programmatic use of typhoid vaccines for controlling endemic disease.

Following review of the available data:

  • SAGE recommended the introduction of typhoid conjugate vaccine (TCV) for infants and children over 6 months of age as a single dose in typhoid endemic countries.
  • Introduction of TCV should first be prioritized to countries with the highest burden of disease or a high burden of antimicrobial resistant S. Typhi.
  • SAGE also recommended catch-up vaccination wherever feasible, with priority for catch-up in the youngest age groups (up to 15 years of age), depending on local epidemiology.

SAGE highlighted the need for countries to strengthen the surveillance of typhoid fever, and to monitor the occurrence of antimicrobial resistant strains of S. typhi in endemic and epidemic disease, before and after programmatic use of TCV.

questions.text: Teriflunomide is used in:
questions.solution:
• Teriflunomide is used in disease-modifying therapy for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis (MS).
  • This drug is a tetrapeptide epoxyketone proteasome inhibitor and it inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase.
  • It reduces the attack rate and improves all measures of disease severity in MS patients.
  • It is given as a tablet at a dose of 14mg or 7mg per day.
  • Its main adverse effects are alopecia, headache, nausea, phosphatemia and diarrhea, amongst others.
  • Update: It was approved in India for this usage in 2017, although it has been in use during in Europe and the US for a few years now.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct thrombin inhibitor used in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia?
questions.solution:
• Agratroban is a univalent, competitive, direct thrombin inhibitor that reversibly binds to thrombin active site.
  • It is indicated for use as a parenteral anticoagulant in prophylaxis or treatment of patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
  • It is also indicated in patients at risk for or with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
  • It prolongs the aPTT, PT and INR. This complicates the transitioning of patients from argatroban to warfarin.
  • It is metabolized in the liver and doesn’t undergo renal clearance.
  • It is recommended not to perform spinal or epidural anesthesia on patients using this drug.
  • Adverse effects include GI bleeding and hematuria. Less common side effects are headache, dyspnea, diarrhea, etc.
  • Other direct thrombin inhibitors are lepirudin, desirudin and bivalirudin.
  • Update: It was approved for usage in these cases in India, in 2017.
  • Fondaparinux is an antithrombotic agent that inhibits factor Xa.
  • Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist.
  • Danaparoid is a mixture of glycosaminoglycans with anti-Xa activity.

questions.text: Which of the following blood glucose levels is classified by American Diabetic Association as glucose alert value (level 1) of hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
American Diabetes Association, in 2017, has proposed new classification for Hypoglycemia which is as follows

Classification of hypoglycemia:

 

Level  Glycemic criteria  Description
Glucose alert value (level 1)  ≤ 70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L) Sufficiently low for treatment with fast-acting carbohydrate and dose adjustment of glucose-lowering therapy
Clinically significant hypoglycemia (level 2)  < 54 mg/dL (3.0 mmol/L) Sufficiently low to indicate serious, clinically important hypoglycemia
Severe hypoglycemia (level 3)  No specific glucose threshold Hypoglycemia associated with severe cognitive impairment requiring external assistance for recovery

A glucose alert value of ≤ 70 mg/dL (3.9 mmol/L) can be important for therapeutic dose adjustment of glucose-lowering drugs in clinical care and is often related to symptomatic hypoglycemia.

questions.solution:

questions.text: The WHO recommends the use of delamanid in the treatment of MDR-TB in all of the following situations except:

choices.text: Intolerance of other second line drugs
Non-compliance to other tolerable second line drugs
Non-availability of other second line drugs

questions.solution:
• Delamanid is a nitroimidazole antibiotic that is used in certain cases of tuberculosis.
  • This drug has been recommended for use by the WHO in cases of multi-drug resistant TB (MDR-TB) when the usual regimen for MDR-TB cannot be followed because of known resistance, intolerance and non-availability of other second-line drugs in the regimen.
  • Delamanid has shown to significantly increase the culture conversion rate at 2 months.
  • The main side effect of this drug is QT prolongation and so cardiac patients on this drug should be closely monitored.
  • This drug was approved for usage in India in 2017. It has been in use in other parts of the world like Europe and Japan for a few years now.

questions.text: The major adverse effect of arbekacin is:
questions.solution:
• Arbekacin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic was discovered in 1972.
  • It is now widely indicated in the treatment of pneumonia, sepsis and infections caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
  • It has shown promise in treating even multi-drug resistant Gram-negative bacterial infections such as P. aeruginosa and Acinetobacter baumannii.
  • Nephrotoxicity is the major adverse effect of this drug. Another side effect is ototoxicity.
  • Update: This drug was approved for usage in India in 2017.

questions.text: Family participatory care guidelines, released by Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, refers to ______

choices.text: Participation of families in community health camps
Family participation for improving newborn health
Family participation for rehabilitation of member with disability

questions.solution:
• Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has released Operational Guidelines for Planning and Implementation of Family Participatory Care (FPC) for improving newborn health.
  • FPC provides for partnership between health care staff and families for care of sick newborn.
  • Under FPC, the capacities of parents-attendants are built in newborn care through a structured training programme (audio -visual module and a training guide).
  • The staff at newborn care unit will provide continuous supervision and support.
  • Provisions for infrastructure and logistics strengthening required for implementing FPC are ensured in the annual state Program Implementation Plan (PIP).
  • In this regard, FPC has emerged as an important concept of health care which provides for partnership between health care staff and families in care of sick newborn admitted in the NICU. The move is expected to bring down infant mortality.

questions.text: The newly detected TB cases throughout India shall now be treated with which of the following regimens?

choices.text: Thrice weekly regimen in intensive phase followed by twice weekly regimen in continuation phase
Twice weekly regimen in intensive phase followed by thrice weekly regimen in continuation phase
Daily regimen in intensive phase followed by twice weekly regimen in continuation phase
Daily regimen in both intensive and continuation phases

questions.solution:
The principle of treatment of TB has been shifted towards daily regimen with administration of daily fixed dose combination of first-line ATD as per appropriate weight bands.

The new daily drug regimen has been adopted under national strategic plan for tuberculosis elimination, 2017-2025.

For new TB cases:

  • Treatment in Intensive phase will consist of 8 weeks of INH, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol in daily dosages as per four weight bands categories
  • Only Pyrazinamide will be stopped in CP while the other three drugs will be continued for another 16 weeks as daily dosages.

questions.text: According to the Indian Medical Devices Rules, 2017, which of the following is correctly matched?
questions.solution:

questions.text: The drug etelcalcetide sometimes causes serious hypocalcemia which requires medical attention. This drug has been approved by the FDA for usage in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Secondary hyperparathyroidism with chronic kidney disease on dialysis
Secondary hyperparathyroidism with chronic kidney disease not on dialysi

questions.solution:
• Etelcalcetide is a calcimimetic agent that modulates the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).
  • It enhances the activation of the receptor by extracellular calcium after it binds to the CaSR.
  • It is currently indicated for secondary hyperparathyroidism for patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) who are on hemodialysis.
  • This drug has not been studied in those with parathyroid carcinoma, primary hyperparathyroidism or CKD, who are not on hemodialysis.
  • It is contraindicated in history of hypersensitivity to the drug.
  • Some adverse effects have been reported like serious hypocalcemia, upper GI bleeding, muscle spasms, nausea, etc.
  • Update: This drug was approved for usage by the U.S. FDA in 2017 and is marketed as Parsabiv. In Europe, it was approved in 2016.

questions.text: World Diabetes Day, which is conducted every year, is an initiative by

questions.text: The intensified mission Indradhanush refers to accelerated full immunization coverage to more than __________
questions.solution:
• Government of India has introduced “Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI)” in select districts and urban areas of the country to achieve the target of more than 90% coverage.
  • The strategy of IMI is to cover all left outs and drop outs in select districts and urban areas with low routine immunization coverage in a specific time-frame (December 2018).
  • IMI will focus on children up to 2 years of age and pregnant women who have missed out on routine immunization. However, vaccination on demand to children up to 5 years of age will be provided during IMI rounds.

questions.text: Edaravone is a novel drug used for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Route of administration of this drug is:
questions.solution:
• Edaravone is a pyrazolone free radical scavenger which is used in the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
  • The mechanism by which it exerts its action in ALS is unknown. It has been theorized that it reduces oxidative stress.
  • It is approved for use as an intravenous infusion.
  • The most common adverse effects of this drug are bruising (contusion) and gait disturbance. Other adverse effects include hives, swelling and shortness of breath.
  • It has been used in Japan to help with recovery from stroke.
  • Update: It was approved by the U.S. FDA in 2017, for usage in ALS. It has been in use earlier in Japan for this purpose.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the safinamide used in Parkinson’s disease (PD)?
questions.solution:
• Safinamide is a monoamine oxidase type-B (MAO-B) inhibitor and blocks the catabolism of dopamine.
  • It is indicated as an add-on to therapy in Parkinson’s disease (PD) in those currently taking levodopa/carbidopa and experiencing ‘off’ episodes.
  • The exact mechanism of its therapeutic effects in PD is not known.
  • It is given orally, at an initial dose of 50mg per day.
  • It has not shown benefits as a part of monotherapy of PD.
  • Adverse effects include dyskinesia, falls, nausea, insomnia, etc.
  • It is contraindicated in severe hepatic impairment. It can exacerbate hypertension when taken with other MAOIs.
  • It is also contraindicated with the use of opioids and tricyclic antidepressants.
  • Update: It was approved for usage in PD by the U.S. FDA in 2017.

questions.solution:

Goals of National Nutrition Strategy:

questions.text: The ‘WATCH’ category, with regards to the newly proposed WHO essential medicines list refers to antibiotics which are:

choices.text: Available at all times as treatments for a wide range of common infections
Recommended as first- or second-choice treatments for a small number of infections
Used as last resort options only in the most severe circumstances

questions.solution:
New advice on which antibiotics to use for common infections and which to preserve for the most serious circumstances is among the additions to the WHO Essential Medicines List (EML), 2017.

In the biggest revision of the antibiotics section in the EML’s 40-year history, WHO experts have grouped antibiotics into three categories – ACCESS, WATCH and RESERVE – with recommendations on when each category should be used.

  • ACCESS group: Antibiotics that are meant to be available at all times as treatments for a wide range of common infections. For example, it includes amoxicillin, a widely-used antibiotic to treat infections such as pneumonia.
  • WATCH group: It includes antibiotics that are recommended as first- or second-choice treatments for a small number of infections. For example, the use of ciprofloxacin, used to treat cystitis (a type of urinary tract infection) and upper respiratory tract infections (such as bacterial sinusitis and bacterial bronchitis), should be dramatically reduced to avoid further development of resistance.
  • RESERVE group: It includes antibiotics such as colistin and some cephalosporins that should be considered last-resort options, and used only in the most severe circumstances when all other alternatives have failed, such as for life-threatening infections due to multidrug-resistant bacteria.

questions.text: The drug padeliporfin used in vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy (VTP) has been approved for use in:
questions.solution:
• Padeliporfin is palladium bacteriopheophorbide photosensitizer that is used for treating men with low-risk cancer prostate (localized).
  • Padeliporfin is used as part of the procedure known as vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy (VTP).
  • In this method, the drug is injected into the patient intravenously. Laser light activates this compound when shone on it through optical fibres inserted into the prostate.
  • Once the compound is activated, it triggers high levels of oxygen radicals to be produced which cause destruction of the blood supply to cancer cells.
  • Most common side effects of this drug are problems with urination, sexual problems, urinary tract infections, blood in urine, etc.
  • It is contraindicated in patients with cholestasis, patients having undergone other prostate operations or those who have flare-ups of inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Update: It was approved for usage in Europe in 2017 by the European Commission under the name Tookad.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the approved usage of ribociclib in breast cancer?

choices.text: Used only in HR positive, HER2 negative advanced breast cancer
It is a cyclin-dependent kinase 5 inhibitor

questions.solution:
• Ribociclib is a cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 inhibitor and it blocks the cellular proliferation of G1 into S phase of the cell cycle.
  • It is indicated for usage in combination with an aromatase as initial endocrine-based therapy for postmenopausal women with hormone receptor (HR)-positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-negative advanced or metastatic breast cancer.
  • It is given orally at a dose of 600mg per day, once daily, for 21 days followed by 7 days off treatment. This will result in a 28-day cycle.
  • Most common adverse effects of this drug include neutropenia, nausea, fatigue, diarrhea, leucopenia, alopecia, vomiting, constipation, back pain and headache.
  • Update: It was approved for usage in India, US and Europe in 2017.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding the new performance and quality measures for myocardial infarction, proposed by ACC/AHA, except ________

choices.text: Non-invasive stress testing before discharge in conservatively treated patients
Early cardiac troponin measurement, within 6 hours of arrival
Early invasive strategy, within 48 hours, in high-risk NSTEMI patients

questions.solution:
American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) have released a new set of performance and quality measures for ST-elevation MI (STEMI) and non-ST-elevation MI (NSTEMI).

The key suggestions are as follows:

Performance measures:

  • Immediate angiography for resuscitated out-of-hospital cardiac arrest in STEMI patients.
  • Non-invasive stress testing before discharge in conservatively treated patients.
  • Early cardiac troponin measurement, within 6 hours of arrival.
  • Participation in a regional or national acute-MI registry.

Quality measures:

  • Risk-score stratification for NSTEMI patients.
  • Early invasive strategy, within 24 hours, in high-risk NSTEMI patients.
  • Therapeutic hypothermia for comatose STEMI patients with out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.
  • Aldosterone antagonist at discharge.
  • Inappropriate in-hospital use of NSAIDs.
  • Inappropriate prescription of prasugrel at discharge in patients with a history of prior stroke or TIA.
  • Inappropriate prescription of high-dose aspirin with ticagrelor at discharge.

questions.text: All of the following are the minor criteria, for the diagnosis of Classical Ehlers Danlos syndrome, except:
questions.solution:
• The Ehlers–Danlos syndromes (EDS) are a heterogeneous group of heritable connective tissue disorders (HCTDs) characterized by joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility.
  • The following diagnostic criteria has been proposed by the 2017 International Classification of the Ehlers–Danlos Syndromes.

Major criteria:

  1. Skin hyperextensibility and atrophic scarring
  2. Generalized joint hypermobility (GJH)

Minor criteria:

  1. Easy bruising
  2. Soft, doughy skin
  3. Skin fragility (or traumatic splitting)
  4. Molluscoid pseudotumors
  5. Subcutaneous spheroids
  6. Hernia (or history thereof)
  7. Epicanthal folds
  8. Complications of joint hypermobility (e.g., sprains, luxation/ subluxation, pain, flexible flatfoot)
  9. Family history of a first degree relative who meets clinical criteria

Minimal diagnostic criteria for classical EDS:

  • Major criterion (1): skin hyperextensibility and atrophic scarring

Plus

  • Either major criterion (2): GJH
  • And/or: at least three minor criteria

Confirmatory molecular testing is obligatory to reach a final diagnosis

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: In 2017, the WHO released a road safety technical package called Save LIVES. Which of the following is not a component of this package?
questions.solution:
• In 2017, the WHO released a road safety technical package called Save LIVES, which collated evidence-based measures that can significantly reduce road traffic fatalities or injuries.

    • L – Leadership
    • I – Infrastructure design and improvement
    • V – Vehicle safety standards
    • E – Enforcement of traffic laws

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.solution:
Orthostatic hypotension is not a core clinical feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD) as per DSM-5.

LBD also known as dementia with Lewy bodies is the second most type of progressive dementia after Alzheimer’s disease. Protein deposits, called Lewy bodies, deposit in nerve cells in the brain region involved in thinking, memory, and movement (motor control)

Core features of LBD as per DSM-5 are fluctuating cognition, attention, alertness, recurrent visual hallucination, and Parkinsonian symptoms. Suggestive features are REM sleep behavior disorder and severe neuroleptic sensitivity.
Orthostatic hypotension, erectile dysfunction, and constipation are other features of LBD.

Treatment of LBD includes rivastigmine and donepezil which may improve cognition, and reduce hallucinosis and delusion. Pimavanserin may be used to treat psychosis.
